review_preview: Recently visited here with my husband; on our first visit there wasn’t a single thing I can criticise. The steak was that tender I could have cut it with a butter knife, the vegetables were tasty and the garlic and herb fries were delicious. All...
review_full: Recently visited here with my husband; on our first visit there wasn’t a single thing I can criticise. The steak was that tender I could have cut it with a butter knife, the vegetables were tasty and the garlic and herb fries were delicious. All of this was finished off with a very tasty crepe. I wish I could say the same for our visit on the last night of our holiday. Again we received a friendly welcome by an English speaking waiter but the visit was let down by our steaks. I ordered medium and my husband ordered medium rare but both were extremely undercooked and had to be sent back. When they were bought back out my husband’s steak was rare but he ate but mine was still raw and cold in the middle. I did tell the waiter and pointed out to him the parts I’d had to leave. At a cost of €100 for two steaks, two sides, two deserts and bottle of wine I did expect more. Mixed feelings as I loved our first visit.

review_preview: Simply put this restaurant is worth your patronage!  This was our last meal in Europe before heading back to the states and what a memorable one it was.  We had tapas at three different restaurants while in the Barcelona and Madrid area and this was...
review_full: Simply put this restaurant is worth your patronage! This was our last meal in Europe before heading back to the states and what a memorable one it was. We had tapas at three different restaurants while in the Barcelona and Madrid area and this was by far the best meal that we had. One of the things that made it so special was the very unique dishes with VERY fresh ingredients, vegetarian friendly and allowed you to have portion control. They had something for everyone. We ordered about 5 different dishes plus 2 desserts. Each of the dishes came out at a different time - you could tell that they were made on the spot that you were not getting anything that seemed to be prepared ahead of time. It was great because you had the chance to savor each one of the dishes before receiving the next and you were not rushed and could enjoy hot dishes hot and cold dishes cold. The bread was warm and tasty it was if they made it just for you! We had one or two meals from each one of the three categories in addition to our dessert. Make sure that you save room for dessert since we had a molten chocolate cake with lavender ice cream that was "to die for"! All that being said the wait staff was extremely warm and friendly... The young lady that took our order asked us how we enjoyed each one of our meals and she was so pleased when we kept on telling her that we did! We also noticed that this restaurant has moved up on the list of restaurants on Trip Advisor since we ate there and it is no wonder that it has. We HIGHLY recommend a visit to this restaurant.

review_preview: We went here for dinner on the off chance they had a table as we were told we couldn't book when we tried earlier. The restaurant has nice decor if maybe a little bright but that is typically Spanish. The tables were a bit too...
review_full: We went here for dinner on the off chance they had a table as we were told we couldn't book when we tried earlier. The restaurant has nice decor if maybe a little bright but that is typically Spanish. The tables were a bit too close together as you could almost join in the conversation with the table next to you. The food was very good, however. We had the Tavola as a starter, which was a selection of starters and was very good. We both had pasta mains and they were also very good. The only complaint was the service was too rushed as were served our main course before we'd finished our starter. We do like to have some time between courses - we're there for a dining experience not a race! Needless to say we didn't order our desserts straight away but when we did they were also very good. Probably would go back if we're in Madrid again but wouldn't go out of our way to do so.

review_preview: I am giving a lot of "excellent" reviews in Spain because Trip Advisor has been a wonderful resource for Madrid, Córdoba, Granada, and Malaga. Taberna Origen is several blocks into a neighborhood outside the tourist areas. It is just to the north of Plaza Espana,...
review_full: I am giving a lot of "excellent" reviews in Spain because Trip Advisor has been a wonderful resource for Madrid, Córdoba, Granada, and Malaga. Taberna Origen is several blocks into a neighborhood outside the tourist areas. It is just to the north of Plaza Espana, which is also a Metro stop. I would never have found it without TripAdvisor. We are making a short stop over in Madrid after almost three weeks in Spain, and the restaurant is just two blocks from our very quiet hotel in a very quiet neighborhood. The space is a bit odd. When we walked in, we though there were only two tables, both occupied, but a very enthusiastic waiter -- and maybe owner -- waived us into a back dining area with another 5 tables. We were in for lunch. My guess is reservations are a must for dinner. Very nicely decorated with white walls, dark furniture, and modern art. Really pleasant. This is a "fusion" restaurant, so knowing exactly what you are getting can be a challenge. They have an English version of the menu, which helps, but exactly what is cod fitters with pad Thai sauce? No one in the restaurant had good English, but we managed to get by with our limited conversational Spanish and a lot of good humor. We were adventurous, and the cod fritters we excellent. I am not sure what the pad Thai sauce was, other than it was light and a great accompaniment. The menu is tapas, media, and raciones, and you will not recognize a single item. Much to our delight, the menu had a number of vegetable options, including a cone of tempura vegetables with teriyaki sauce that was as fabulous as we had hoped. Our waiter helped us not over order by advising us to order media when our impulse was raciones. We were started with complementary tiny Spanish omelettes, which were a fusion of a German potato pancake and the ubiquitous Spanish omelette. Very delicate and an interesting twist. Cannot go wrong with potatoes in our book. A highlight for us was the boletus mushroom croquettes, which were all mushroom -- no cheese -- and just a burst of flavor. We also went for the tomato plate advised by several reviewers, and it was also surprising. What appeared were two beautifully vine ripened tomatoes still on the vine that were baked and had honey drizzled over them. Inside was a stuffing of sheep cheese chopped very fine. Amazing flavor.  In addition to the vegetable tempura and cod fritters, we also had a seafood lasagna with tomato, which included two very nice grilled scallops. I was expecting tomato sauce, but what came was deconstructed and had a cream sauce that beautifully played background to the seafood. The tomato was fresh slices with rounds of al dente pasta, almost like ravioli rounds. This was a meal of wonderful surprises that used the tapas format to great advantage without being greasy bar food. This is an inventive kitchen that loves food and knows cuisine. Total bill for two was €36, which is a bargain for two people. The overall menu, which we did not begin to sample, is organized into sections with vegetables, fish and seafood, and meat. We did not try anything from the meat section. The restaurant describes itself as fusion, and it is. It pays to be adventurous, because I am not sure that even with impeccable Spanish our preconceptions would have not carried the day. And this is the point of the restaurant: taking the dominant Spanish form and surprising you with wonderful food you could not imagine. I wish we had this restaurant in our home town. I just hope it's blooming success does not kill it.

title_review: So good, we ate here twice!
review_preview: On our first night in Madrid, we were looking for a straightforward Italian place with good pizza, pasta, etc.  Oven Atocha did not disappoint.  I highly recommend the vegetable pizza, the four cheese pizza, the Margherita pizza, and the ceviche.  For the pizzas, the whole...
review_full: On our first night in Madrid, we were looking for a straightforward Italian place with good pizza, pasta, etc. Oven Atocha did not disappoint.  I highly recommend the vegetable pizza, the four cheese pizza, the Margherita pizza, and the ceviche. For the pizzas, the whole wheat crust option is particularly delicious. Our group ordered various pizzas and dishes and shared them -- the pizzas are more than big enough for a single person.  The interior of the restaurant is comfortable and offers a lively feel without being overly loud.  The service was also excellent; Lidia provided great suggestions and was very attentive. Our experience the first night was so good that we returned on our final night in Madrid, and the experience was equally wonderful. I highly recommend this restaurant and hope to have the opportunity to return someday!

review_preview: Our last night in Madrid was our wedding anniversary so we wanted somewhere special to come for dinner, we came across this place on Trip Advisor after searching for Italian restaurants and we were certainly not disappointed with our choice! It was quite quiet when...
review_full: Our last night in Madrid was our wedding anniversary so we wanted somewhere special to come for dinner, we came across this place on Trip Advisor after searching for Italian restaurants and we were certainly not disappointed with our choice! It was quite quiet when we arrived (7.00pm is quite early in Spanish terms!) but there was still a good atmosphere and it started getting busier as the night went on. The service was very efficient and most importantly our food was delicious! Tasted like authentic Italian food and not mass produced like you sometimes find in chain restaurants. Considering we had ordered a bottle of champagne the final bill was very reasonable too. We will definitely come back here if we ever return to Madrid!

A must try establishment!

review_full: Top notch food and service in an unassuming little restaurant on a quiet little street just off Plaza de Espana. The food is excellent - the best I have eaten on my travels in a long time. The staff were extremely friendly and helpful, and even though no English was spoken we had no problems communicating. Unsurprisingly it gets very busy at lunchtimes, but thankfully it seems the Spanish take their lunches much later than the rest of Europe, so we turned up at 1pm to an almost entirely empty place. By the time we left people were waiting for our spot.

title_review: Excellent food and very friendly stuff
review_preview: Thanks to Tripadvisor recommendation we had a fantastic lunch at this tapas bar in Madrid. Located near Plaza de Espana, is easy to reach. Better to have a reservation before, because the place is small and known for its quality food, so it was almost...
review_full: Thanks to Tripadvisor recommendation we had a fantastic lunch at this tapas bar in Madrid. Located near Plaza de Espana, is easy to reach. Better to have a reservation before, because the place is small and known for its quality food, so it was almost full. The staff is very friendly and smiley. They menu is not a rich one, but every dish we tasted was more then excellent. We loved the avocado ice cream with tuna tartare , cuttlefish burger, some interesting potato called Ana's potato and many more. But for the desert the surprise came from some kind of chocolate mouse with violet ice cream! The price was very decent. We had a great time and looking forward to come back!

This is not the cheapest meal you could have but excellent value for an great meal.

review_preview: A fantastic restaurant just behind the Plaza Mayor and away from the tourist traps. Nice decor and great friendly service! We opted for the degustation menu along with paired wines. A wonderful culinary experience whether it was the salmorejo, the sea anemone (a must!), the...
review_full: A fantastic restaurant just behind the Plaza Mayor and away from the tourist traps. Nice decor and great friendly service! We opted for the degustation menu along with paired wines. A wonderful culinary experience whether it was the salmorejo, the sea anemone (a must!), the escalivada, the scallop with black rice risotto, the smoked suckling pig or the 2 desserts. We couldn't agree on a favourite. They were also so accommodating by replacing the chocolate dessert for one of our party who doesn't like chocolate. The chef Mattias Smith was even at hand to tell us about one of his amazing dishes.

Great strategy because then you can sample lots of dishes and choose your favorite for a meal. Some of the tapas were a little on the small side, like the salmorejo. Their signature dishes were the tomatoe and cheese, perfect flavor and texture, and their cheesecake, homemade and a sheer delight with great texture and a lovely hint of cinnamon. A generous wine taste, half a glass, before we actually chose the house white. We sat at the bar by the window and that suited us fine. A well deserved reputation and a return visit a must. Thank you to the very friendly and efficient staff.

title_review: Best meal of the year - so far - Plaza Mayor
review_preview: We are staying in the Plaza Mayor and discovered this gem of a restaurant nearby. It's modern Spanish (unlike its neighbors) and a beautifully constructed experience. Modern decor, welcoming and very helpful waitstaff and creative cooking.  We started with a gin and tonic (Citedelle served...
review_full: We are staying in the Plaza Mayor and discovered this gem of a restaurant nearby. It's modern Spanish (unlike its neighbors) and a beautifully constructed experience. Modern decor, welcoming and very helpful waitstaff and creative cooking.  We started with a gin and tonic (Citedelle served with fresh lemon grass). The house made smoked tuna salads with gazpacho dressing were a standout. But the mains were even better - baked Guinea fowl served on roasted eggplant and Iberian pork in a sweet and sour sauce. Spectacular.  The desert of four types of chocolate was a lovely decadent OTT ending. Highly recommend - top drawer cooking and hospitality at a very reasonable price.

review_preview: We have just come back from a lovely long week-end in Madrid which was made even better after visiting Metro Bistro. We went on the Saturday night and decided to have the 7 course tasting menu at €34 per head. Every course was unusual, beautifully...
review_full: We have just come back from a lovely long week-end in Madrid which was made even better after visiting Metro Bistro. We went on the Saturday night and decided to have the 7 course tasting menu at €34 per head. Every course was unusual, beautifully presented and explained in detail by our attentive waitress Michela. The service was very friendly and professional.  We had such a lovely evening that we decided to return again on the Sunday night. We again were looked after by Michela who when we said we would like the tasting menu again, spent time with us going through each course on the menu and made suggestions for different options. We ended up having a completely different tasting menu except for the cold soup starter and mango dessert which were both too good to not have again. The second tasting menu was even more incredible than the day before.  Taking into consideration the food, decor, service and price we both felt this was one of the best meals we have ever had and are only sad that the restaurant is based in Madrid and not somewhere in London where we can visit regularly! Highly recommended.

title_review: If you want to be EXCELLENT, try being consistently GOOD first!
review_preview: We had read about this downtown restaurant, liked the sound of it, and with the help of "recepcion" at the excellent "Catalonia Las Cortes" hotel, had booked a table for Friday night dinner. Still adjusting to local late-eating habits, we were the first to arrive...
review_full: We had read about this downtown restaurant, liked the sound of it, and with the help of "recepcion" at the excellent "Catalonia Las Cortes" hotel, had booked a table for Friday night dinner. Still adjusting to local late-eating habits, we were the first to arrive on the night - it's a modern, well-appointed premises on Calle Imperial, with predominantly black/white decor + beaty music. Our welcome was friendly, and we had the distinct advantage of being able to pick a table. The Menu indicated a reasonable choice of Starters : my "Better Half" M selected a "Hummus" dish, while I went for the "Home-made Foie Terrine". The choice of Mains was disappointing : Squid, an obscure Japanese Fish, "Spanish style" Sweet & Sour Pork, Steak Tartare, and, believe it or not, Hamburger! Em, we both felt our only reasonable option was the Hamburger, despite the fact that we've eaten in more than a few restaurants with widely varying influences. As for wine, we attempted to order the seemingly better of the Rias Baixas offerings, but had to settle for the lesser option, making us wonder how much of the presented list was actually available? Anyway, we ordered, and as a preliminary we were presented with a "Celery Mojito" - our Server glowingly talked this up (a practice we discovered is part of the restaurant's approach) and it was quite tasty. As for our actual Starters, M pronounced her Hummus "very tasty", and my "Terrine", while beautifully presented, suffered from being too chilled, obscuring the flavour. Style, presentation and description are clearly "big" here, and we'll come back to that. Our Burgers (!) were in a kind-of layered format : M's was cooked as requested, while mine was nothing like the "medium-well" I had asked for in both Spanish & English. With a bit of "theatre" my Burger was taken back and replaced - one of the layers this time was about right, the other not. We sampled one of the Desserts - an apple crumble - again introduced to us with elaborate, glowing descriptions of its ingredients, and it was fair enough. Before the end, we were presented with fancy pastille-type sweets, on a special piece of stone (of course!). Our conclusion about this meal + our experience at "Metro Bistro" is simply this : you're clearly aspiring to be something "different", but before you get to be "excellent", you need to consistently get the "basics" right. For example, your choice of "Mains" is poor, and if you insist on including Hamburger, get the cooking right ; secondly, ensure that when the customer needs cutlery, he/she has it ; thirdly, if you're bringing a meal course to the table, make sure the last course has been cleared, if only for space reasons. And above all, don't confuse "talking-up" and "fancy presentation" with delivery of a good food & service product! Our Bill (pre-gratuity) was a very reasonable Euro 66-60, and we would commend our main Server Michaela for her good-humoured efforts.

review_preview: We were not having good luck with the restaurant scene in Madrid. Finally my husbands work mates took us to the Metro Bistro since we were visiting the Mercado by the Plaza Mayor. What a treat. First they brought out this celery concoction drink that...
review_full: We were not having good luck with the restaurant scene in Madrid. Finally my husbands work mates took us to the Metro Bistro since we were visiting the Mercado by the Plaza Mayor. What a treat. First they brought out this celery concoction drink that was surprisingly great on such a hot day. We then had several appetizers that included a great foie gras terrine and s garlic shrimp dish that was divine!. But hands down the lamp entrée was the best lamb I ever had. It was slow cooked and served on a pureed truffled potato with crispy fried mushrooms on top. I was in heaven. The work mate across from me got the same and practically licked the plate. We got a variety of desserts that were all good. The service could have been a little better. (we wanted more wine!) But the prices were exceptional for such a good meal. We went back four days later to experience it again.

We’ve had a lot of salmorejo in Spain but this topped them all with olive oil ice cream. Our main courses included delectable bacon and beef burgers, marinated vegetables with eel, and steak tartare to die for. The dessert, Tribute to Chocolate, was four different tastings of chocolate including one with pepper and one with chocolate that popped in the mouth. They also served complimentary fruit jellies. All equally exquisite and delicious. Miguel, our waiter, was attentive and kind. Our daughter spilled on her dress and without asking, Miguel brought us stain remover and a brush! So thoughtful! Don’t come to Madrid without this treat of a meal!

review_preview: We just returned from three weeks in Spain, and this was by far the best meal we had on the entire trip.  We had heard that Madrid rivaled Barcelona with regard to good food, but we had not been very impressed with the cuisine in...
review_full: We just returned from three weeks in Spain, and this was by far the best meal we had on the entire trip. We had heard that Madrid rivaled Barcelona with regard to good food, but we had not been very impressed with the cuisine in Madrid before eating here. We wandered in about 7:30, hoping to make reservations for another night. They offered to take us on the spot, provided we promised to be done by 9:30 p.m. - no problem!! The interior decor is very modern but in a warm and inviting way. The wait staff were all very good, but especially Miguel. He was amazingly friendly and helpful, explaining each dish as he served it. We started with the complimentary celery mojito, which was absolutely wonderful - wish we could make that one at home! I had the salmorejo, the tipico cold tomato soup, which was out of this world. My husband had roasted potatoes with three different "dips" - he was delighted with all three. There was also a variety of breads which were divine, and I'm not a big bread eater. We both enjoyed our main course - the lamb was especially good - and we even managed dessert. After three weeks of good to very good food, this was the first really magnificent meal we had - one night before returning home. Don't miss eating here if you are in Madrid, just off Plaza Mayor on C. Imperial. Be sure to make reservations because they are VERY popular. We were just lucky they took pity on us!!

review_preview: After reading reviews of Metro Bistro on Tripadvisor, we decided to try it. I asked about reservations via email and received a prompt and polite reply.Metro Bistro is on the far side of Plaza Mayor, but it doesn't have that tourist feel to it....
review_full: After reading reviews of Metro Bistro on Tripadvisor, we decided to try it. I asked about reservations via email and received a prompt and polite reply. Metro Bistro is on the far side of Plaza Mayor, but it doesn't have that tourist feel to it. We didn't want to go tourist, and MB most certainly was the best place we could have chosen. We started with a cheese plate and croquetas which were both great. I want to point out that we mentioned not liking bleu cheese, and they substituted for us. My husband had the pork, and i had the hamburger. I wanted the lamb but ended up with the burger because the veal/bacon combination sounded good. Both of our meals were delicious. We liked all of the breads, although we thought the cocoa/herb bread was a little weird. As others have mentioned, they started us with a celery mojito and finished the meal with amaretto and passion fruit jells. I have to say I loved the celery mojito. One note about service: We had two servers—a female and a male. The woman was kind enough, but she was not as warm and friendly as the man. I'm guessing the waiter's name was Ibrahim, although I'm not sure. He explained how he made the mojito, and when I accidentally fell getting out of the booth, he was right there to help me get up, get me water/wine/whatever. If we ever get back to Madrid, we will definitely go back.

title_review: Favorite meal during my tour of Spain
review_preview: Came here for my final dinner of my 10-day tour of Spain after reading the reviews on TripAdvisor.  Travelled through Barcelona, Valencia, Granada, Seville, and Madrid, and this was my favorite meal by far.  Our sever, Ibrahim, was top notch and explained everything (in English!)...
review_full: Came here for my final dinner of my 10-day tour of Spain after reading the reviews on TripAdvisor. Travelled through Barcelona, Valencia, Granada, Seville, and Madrid, and this was my favorite meal by far. Our sever, Ibrahim, was top notch and explained everything (in English!) on the menu to us in detail, while starting our meal off with a small celery mojito sample and some various delicious breads/butters. We began with the Potatoes with 3 sauces, which I highly recommend. My entree was a Japanese butterfish in ponzu sauce and my friend got stuffed calamari. Both fantastic. Finshed off with the "Tribute to Chocolate" Dessert. Get this, you won't be disappointed. Total bill with 2 drinks was under 70 euros.

title_review: Great food and personal service for a very reasonable price
review_preview: After first finding their other location in Madrid closed we unintentionally stumbled onto the other location in the city center. After entering we were kindly seated even though we didn't have a reservation. We immediately got a small appetiser (celery mojito) and were presented with...
review_full: After first finding their other location in Madrid closed we unintentionally stumbled onto the other location in the city center. After entering we were kindly seated even though we didn't have a reservation. We immediately got a small appetiser (celery mojito) and were presented with the menu. After looking at it a while the waiter arrived and explained the 7 course menu to us and which courses it contained.  This option sounded pretty impressive for a very reasonable price that we both took it. All courses were of a nice size, so that you didn't feel overly full after the 5 normal dishes and 2 desserts. Every course was brought out quickly, but not too quick, at the perfect temperature and each time accompanied by a short introduction/explanation by the waiter. After the second dessert we each got 2 small home made candies (amaretto & passion fruit) to round off a very pleasant evening after which we gladly paid the very reasonable bill.

title_review: One of the best meals anywhere!
review_preview: So we're not Michelin star diners as I don't want to eat some of the odder things prepared in those restaurants. But we are foodies and pretty good cooks ourselves, and we use our own capabilities as a standard of sorts. Metro Bistro blew us away!!...
review_full: So we're not Michelin star diners as I don't want to eat some of the odder things prepared in those restaurants. But we are foodies and pretty good cooks ourselves, and we use our own capabilities as a standard of sorts. Metro Bistro blew us away!! Chef Matias Smith personally engaged with us, helped with wine selection and checked in on every course.  One of the best meals we’ve eaten in many years! Loved the little starter of a celery mojito - we're going to have to try and duplicate that at home! Every single dish was sublime, but particularly the croquetas and the lamb. The challenge to the evening was the party of 48 who took all the remaining tables and elevated the noise level half way through our time there, but Chef Smith appeared with a glass of port for each of us as a thank you for working with them. Next time in Madrid we will be back!

title_review: WOW - Delicioso! And at such great value
review_preview: So this one evening my colleague wasn't keen on going out to dinner so I ended up dining alone. Booked through email a few hours before with no issues.Was a little concerned when I showed up at 9 pm and the place was practically...
review_full: So this one evening my colleague wasn't keen on going out to dinner so I ended up dining alone. Booked through email a few hours before with no issues. Was a little concerned when I showed up at 9 pm and the place was practically empty barring an American couple. But, I quickly decided on the 7-course menu degustacion (tasting menu) as I love chefs showcasing the best of what they can offer and I eat pretty much anything. Course after course of sumptious, delicious plates were put in front of me. Most of which didn't really look or feel much smaller than full sized plates (I compared with a couple of tables nearby who ordered ala carte). Here's what I got...(more or less since the waiter didn't speak too much English and my Spanish is basic at best). - Celery (and apple?) mojito amuse bouche: Delightfully refreshing shot - Salmorejo (typical cold Spanish tomato soup) with pesto oil and olive oil ice cream - 3 breads: Rosemary/chocolate/orange; White; Corn & chilli with rosemary butter and black olive butter. I only really liked the dark rosemary bread tbh - Terrine of foie gras and orange with a puree that tasted a little like plum - Stack of confit vegetables with salsa Romesco and some kind of fish slices - Squid stuffed with ham on a bed of black risotto and turmeric (or safron?) cream - perfectly cook and delicious! - Loin of pork that managed to be pink on the inside (sous vide?) and a bit crispy on the outside, with a red wine reduction, serviced with crispy filo rolls filled with red cabbage and a blueberry paste - Mango mouse, with mango slices wrapped around set yogurt - Death by Chocolate: Ultra light mousse, dense mousse, chocolate truffle and a small pot of warm chocolate sauce (I'm sure there's a more fancy word) with popping candy - loved loved the warm chocolate with popping candy! - Pastilles of amaretto and passion fruit I absolutely cleaned my plate. Some very accomplished (and technical) cooking and very few things that I didn't care for (mostly the bread). The price for all this? €32!! In the UK I've paid about £50 for the same quality and less food. Service was pretty attentive (they took time to explain the elements of the dish to me), although felt a bit rushed when the place filled up (after 10 pm). The clientelle is quite tourist based (probably both thanks to TripAdvisor and its location just outside of Plaza Mayor), but don't let that put you off, it really is excellent modern cooking with traditional influences. It's number 1 on my list of restaurants to come back to next time I'm in Madrid.

review_preview: Metro Bistro is across the street from Plaza Mayor and a world away from the tourist traps selling overpriced and mediocre food.  Metro offers up creative Spanish cuisine in a modern and comfortable setting.  The croquettes were a great way to start (12 crispy pieces...
review_full: Metro Bistro is across the street from Plaza Mayor and a world away from the tourist traps selling overpriced and mediocre food. Metro offers up creative Spanish cuisine in a modern and comfortable setting. The croquettes were a great way to start (12 crispy pieces for just 8.9E) and I absolutely loved the Gigot lamb entree - wonderfully tender and tasty meat. Our table also enjoyed the Black Pearl - black rice risotto topped with three small scallops. The service was excellent and the prices very fair. Do come here for a meal if you can!

title_review: Must Try After Days of Tappas
review_preview: We were ready for something different.  We found it at Metro Bistro.  The restaurant is easily located in the Central part of the city, easy to find and get to by foot.  We were greeted immediately by very friendly staff.  They seated our party of...
review_full: We were ready for something different. We found it at Metro Bistro. The restaurant is easily located in the Central part of the city, easy to find and get to by foot. We were greeted immediately by very friendly staff. They seated our party of 6 in the lovely back room that allowed easy conversation and a round table. We are a mixed diet party with one very strict vegetarian, four that prefer fish and vegetarian diet and one without limits. The menu here was suited for all but our very strict vegetarian guest. Were all disappointed by the choice of grilled vegetables when it arrived at her plate at room temperature and molded with eel on top. This was not described at all in the menu or by the waiter. We also were surprised by the house salad. The figs and lettuce varieties were nice, as was the dressing, but the goat cheese was a full round of cheese, and was far too much. We found a nice wine selection with prices ranging appropriately and many options. We enjoyed the appetizers: the bread selection, cheeses and the chef’s take on potatoes.  The main courses we shared included the Black Pearl—a scallops and black risotto dish with a curry sauce. This was delicious and fun but not the risotto you would likely expect. If you are not willing to experiment this might not be your choice. Two in our party ordered the Cod Casserole. The portion of fish was large. The sauce and vegetables were heavy and the fish was a bit overwhelmed by the surroundings. The Butter Fish was the best item on the menu. The fish was firm, well cooked and surrounded by a ginger and teriyaki based sauce. Very nice and a great treat.  But save space for the dessert. This was the gem of this visit. We ordered 2 for the table, the Chocolate and the Apple Tat. Our waiter recommended the proper order to eat the 5 separate chocolates and he was completely correct. WOW. The apple dessert was a great contrast. These are a must try if you choose this restaurant. After a 5 day visit, you should give it a try.

title_review: A real treat moments from P. Major
review_preview: Thank you TripAdvisor for another great recommendation. We spotted this place last night, but were too early to really appreciate it, so arrived later this evening, sat happily in the window and were treated to a great 3 course evening meal. The freshly made, and...
review_full: Thank you TripAdvisor for another great recommendation. We spotted this place last night, but were too early to really appreciate it, so arrived later this evening, sat happily in the window and were treated to a great 3 course evening meal.  The freshly made, and imaginative bread (inc cacao and orange), served with rosemary butter and olive butter, set the stage well for later courses. Next up, the recommended croquettes and also veal with cream cheese. Both beautifully presented and delicious.  My teenage daughter then chose the squid on black risotto - which was very good - whilst I had the Spanish pork - again excellent. We thought we'd saved space for pudding - but were pretty much beaten by the chocolate dish - which could easily be shared by two!! Full and happy, and having received very good service throughout, we left feeling very lucky indeed! A note on timing - 2030 is fine if you haven't reserved and don't mind a window seat - but if you want to sit in the main restaurant (which almost looked too 'posh' (we preferred the bar area and more relaxed dining) - then reserve a table between 2100 and 2200 and you'll find yourself in a lively, trendy restaurant. Oh - don't miss the cocktails either!

We arrived at 8.30pm to be the first customers and by 9.30 the place was packed with a very lively atmosphere. The staff were extremely friendly and helpful and an English version of the menu was certainly useful. Every dish we ordered was beautifully prepared and presented, the portion size perfect and the taste delicious. We shared 6 tapas, mainly vegetarian and finished with a lime crème brûlée to die for! The price for such quality was very reasonable.  Although we ate in restaurants in 3 other cities over 2 weeks, Taberna Origen kept its place as our favourite!

review_preview: The new hubby and I went out to Origen after watching the sunset at the Temple Debod. It was an unassuming place a few streets down but was already quite packed so we were seated at the bar. I was a little unsure about the...
review_full: The new hubby and I went out to Origen after watching the sunset at the Temple Debod. It was an unassuming place a few streets down but was already quite packed so we were seated at the bar. I was a little unsure about the tight space but the staff worked it very well!  We've been staying in an area where English is not prevalent so we again used (our terrible) Spanish to order but they offered us menus in English so we didn't have to struggle through the translations. We ordered the croquettes (not the shrimp ones), the cuttlefish burger, the steak tartar, and the oxtail to start with a bottle of wine (el bruja). They brought us some fresh bread and gazpacho of (I believe) beet juice and olive oil. It was extremely delicious and hinted at the delicacies to come! The croquettes came a few minutes after we had finished our starter and I was happily surprised to find they were stuffed with cream of mushroom! (Cream of mushroom is one of my favorite things ever invented). So if mushrooms are a favorite, the croquettes are definitely a must!! The cuttlefish burger, again came a few minutes after we had finished and our plates had been cleared, was amazing. The aioli was delicious with the fish (but not overpowering) and very tender fish. This was the hubby's most favorite. Next the steak tartar, very delicious and fresh! Seasoned similarly to a classical deviled egg with stone mustard and slightly sweet bits of pickle. The last "entree" was the only entree we ordered not tapas sized (because it was only available in 1/2 or full size). The oxtail was off the bone, and encased in a sausage casing and covered in sauce. I'm not a huge fan of shredded meat due to chunks of fat it it was tender and delicious! We had a little room for dessert so we ordered the cheesecake with the trio of jams. Delicious cheesecake (although I saw them microwave it quickly before serving which had worried me) and the jams were delicious but not necessarily the best I've had. The jams were an orange peel & honey, raspberry, and peach. The orange jam was slightly bitter on its own, but with the cheesecake it was more balanced. The raspberry was good and the peach was the hubby's favorite but I thought it tasted a little too sweet. Overall, we spent just a little under 50€ for the two of us and left stuffed so I thought it was reasonable but not the "cheapest" meal we've had (and we visited other restaurants that were amazing). I'd say definitely worth going and if you are looking to spend less, order a few tapas before visiting somewhere else for more food!

review_preview: Metro Bistro was literally steps from the front door of our rental apartment in Plaza Mayor. I had read that it was one of the top restaurants in the area and we walked in without a reservation. Amazingly, they had a table for 3 and...
review_full: Metro Bistro was literally steps from the front door of our rental apartment in Plaza Mayor. I had read that it was one of the top restaurants in the area and we walked in without a reservation. Amazingly, they had a table for 3 and seated us immediately. I had the salad with the goat cheese and figs and it was very good. My friends had the potatoes with three sauces which I tried and it was very good. I had the lamb after hearing rave reviews about it and it was good, although I have had better lamb dishes in my life. My friend had the butter fish which was very good and my other friend had the lacquered guinea hen which was really wonderful. I actually can't recall what we had for desert! The only complaint I had with the evening is that everyone else got a celery mojitio but our table. I am not sure if it was an oversight or intentional but I was bummed because they looked really good. Oh well. Maybe if we return to Madrid next time.

review_preview: Just off the Plaza Major this modern looking restaurant was very quiet on a Sunday evening. We had the seven course tasting menu. Not only was it substantial but every course was beautifully presented and provided a wonderful array of flavours. A free aperitif was...
review_full: Just off the Plaza Major this modern looking restaurant was very quiet on a Sunday evening. We had the seven course tasting menu. Not only was it substantial but every course was beautifully presented and provided a wonderful array of flavours. A free aperitif was followed by three kinds of home baked bread and two flavours of butter. The bread was excellent. Pumpkin soup with a cheese in pastry was followed by crispy anemones. Then we had a vegetable dish with smoked eel and a scallop with black rice. A rich and tender lamb stew completed the mains. First dessert was cool, light and fruity followed by a chocolate selection that was too indulgent to resist. All this for 38 euros per person. Our waiters were all friendly and one spoke very good English, explaining the food as we went along. Wines were reasonably priced. Recommended.

review_preview: My partner and I recently ate here, saving it for our last dinner in Madrid. We were seated quickly without a reservation at around 9:40pm on a weeknight. We ordered the variety of meats to share along with a side of garlic and parsley chips/fries....
review_full: My partner and I recently ate here, saving it for our last dinner in Madrid. We were seated quickly without a reservation at around 9:40pm on a weeknight. We ordered the variety of meats to share along with a side of garlic and parsley chips/fries.  When we were sat down we were brought bread and olives. There was a garlic butter too which was very tasty. The bread is not free which might have been naive of me to think so but worth the about €3.50 I believe it cost. The variety of meats were the perfect size to share and delicious. We were brought out the wrong side, a plate of vegetables and the waitress, Laury, who brought them seemed to get annoyed with us when I brought it to her attention that the wrong side had been brought. I understand I’m working with high school level Spanish and that a language barrier can be frustrating, but I was able to say that we had ordered fries in Spanish. I found the huffing and attitude of the waitress while I tried my best to remember certain words to be off putting and it made us not order dessert like we had planned to. Anyway, we were then brought out normal fries. A bit of confusion with the language barrier with Laury and another member of staff but finally the garlic and parsley chips made their way to the table. These chips are the only part of the food that I can fault. They were soggy and honestly seemed like they had been microwaved.  When the bill arrived (after asking for it multiple times), it was wrong. We had been charged for sides that had been brought out in the error of the restaurant. We were given some after dinner liquor as a result of the wait, much appreciated! Also, thank you to Sebastian who helped to sort the errors on the bill out!  We had ordered wine as well with our meal and were finishing it after the meal. The waitress came by our table picking things up in a rush and putting her arms in between the view of my partner and I. I understand that cleaning and picking up has to be done, but I’ve also eaten in enough restaurants to know there’s a more professional manner in which to do so. The food is good here and I try to not let one bad apple ruin it all but it can be hard to enjoy the food when the atmosphere is wrong.

The staff were friendly, helpful, attentive and efficient. My Hubby had the provolone to start, we both had the beef tenderloin with pepper sauce and I finished with the pancake with dulce de leche. Everything was really excellent and I did not see anyone not seeming to enjoy their meals. Tables were filled again as soon as people left, but we didn't feel hurried. It isn't cheap, but you get what you pay for and for Madrid prices for good dining, it was about the going rate. We would definitely go again if we went back to Madrid.

review_full: We've visited this place 3 times on a 9 day visit to Madrid. One of us is a pescetarian, and raved over the grilled salmon. Others have tried the bife de chorizo, and the skirt steak, and started thanking god. Usually the bife is my usual favorite (and was great!), but the skirt steak was out of this world!! It was just right, delicious,a and huge (and I'm a guy who had many of those in Brazilian churrascarias :)). The salad of the house, fries, stir fried veggies, all winners. The young ladies who service the restaurant, are kind and professional. The decor and ambiance just make you feel like the worries of the world are peeled off of you. Very recommended for all meat lovers, and pescetarians too (there is a cod on the menu, but we haven't tried it)

Do yourself a favour and make sure this restaurant is on your list!

My partner asked for medium well and it was cooked perfectly.  I must also mention Sebastian who worked behind the bar who was English and dealt with any English speaking customers and took the phone calls if they were English. He was very polite, friendly and professional.

title_review: What a find off the beaten track but close enough to the bus route
review_preview: We stumbled across this place as we stepped off the tour bus route.  We wanted to get off just before the Grand Palace to avoid the crowds in the hope of finding somewhere more traditional - so glad we did.  As we stepped off the...
review_full: We stumbled across this place as we stepped off the tour bus route. We wanted to get off just before the Grand Palace to avoid the crowds in the hope of finding somewhere more traditional - so glad we did. As we stepped off the bus tour I turned to my reliable trip advisor app in terms of where was nearby and here we landed. It is off a wee back street so as you are walking down you are not too sure what to expect. When we walked in we were greeted by a very warm host who offered us a table and swiftly a menu and drinks. The menu was so varied we wanted to try quite a few things - they split it into things from the sea, garden and land which was a nice way to know what you were eating and how to split your choices. We got a variety of dishes and shared them - the highlights being stuffed potatoes with mushrooms and apricot, sea bass ceviche and the rigatoni pasta which was also amazing. For some of the dishes they have the option of tapas, 1/2 portion and full portion which was helpful when you may want a bit more of some dishes. The staff were very helpful in telling us what would be a right amount for us and recommending their local specialities. Would definately recommend this place for traditional tapas to anyone visiting madrid.

The chocolate fondant with violet ice cream was like no other! The cheesecake with assorted jams is perfect for any sweet tooth. All staff went above and beyond for us, especially Alfonzo who offered many suggestions and even gave us a free shot on the house. Thank you for a fabulous dining experience and we look forward to returning in the future.

review_full: Metro Bistro is very close to Plaza Mayor. To tell the truth, the restaurants around is mostly below/around average and making mass production. However, Plaza Mayor is an exception. The menu is very well designed and all details are being considered by the Chef. Any plate you will order is complex with many details inside. The presentation of the food is perfect. You will enjoy whatever you eat there. You will find classics with a modern interpretation (but keeping the soul of the classics). They serve “Metro Potatoes” with three traditional sauces; each of them is legendary, you should taste them. Croquettes, Cured veal meat, Braised butterfish were all perfect. Service is welcoming and friendly. Prices are really reasonable.

title_review: I didn’t think it could get better, but it did
review_preview: My husband and I have been in España for 5 weeks and we have eaten very very well each night, thanks to the guidance of TA. This was night #6 in Madrid so we’ve tried a few restaurants here and all over the country. With...
review_full: My husband and I have been in España for 5 weeks and we have eaten very very well each night, thanks to the guidance of TA.  This was night #6 in Madrid so we’ve tried a few restaurants here and all over the country. With just one night to go, Metro Bistro Plaza Mayor has to be número uno. And I didn’t think it could get this good.  We arrived back in Madrid a bit late and asked the hotel to book the other Metro Bistro as we had been there before and wanted to go again. It isn’t open on Sunday so we walked to Plaza Mayor to try this one.  At about 9:30pm the restaurant was able to fit us in for dinner - a plus for us - and so it was to be a great experience.  It is my husband’s job to choose the wine and me, the food. He chose a Martin Berlugo Tempranillo - a good choice. I chose the flaming prawns with mushrooms and the slow cooked egg with mushrooms to start - both were magnificent.  We weren’t particularly starving hungry so for main we shared the black rice with scallops and a salad with figs and cheese for main. Those were the best scallops I’ve ever had and the yellow curry sauce with the rice was enhanced by the red wine like you couldn’t imagine.  No room for dessert.  Very good value at EUR78, including refreshing agua con gas for 2.

review_preview: On a recent tour of Spain with a major tour company we enjoyed the company of two other couples and descended on the Metro Bistro.  You can skip Botin and go to the Metro.  The food was exquisite and the staff was very solicitous.  We...
review_full: On a recent tour of Spain with a major tour company we enjoyed the company of two other couples and descended on the Metro Bistro. You can skip Botin and go to the Metro. The food was exquisite and the staff was very solicitous.  We each had the 7 course tasting menu. The staff was very attentive to one of our groups dietary needs and they slightly amended the courses. Each couple ordered a bottle of wine. The meal was not rushed and at each course the chef (Matias Smith) came out to let us know what we were eating and ensure we well taken care of.  Highlights included a cold tomato garlic soup, scallops on black rice and roast pork. All dishes were wonderful. It was great to finish the meal off with a 4 chocolate dessert.  I HIGHLY recommend a visit to this restaurant. Everyone in our group agreed it was the best meal of our trip. The 7 course tasting menu was 38 Euros each. It did not include the wine.

We are seated easily around 8:45pm on a Saturday. Ordered two entrees, dessert and a cheese plate to share. The flavors here are really interesting, nothing is "plain" but also nothing is special without being delicious also. Even the butter that comes with the bread is flavored (we had one sage and one olive). Or entrees were the fish and the scallops, both of which had some hint of eastern flavor. Scallops were my favorite. The service was so lovely - so friendly and welcoming. They were giving tables samples of a cucumber drink they made. Our table ordered one. After we paid our check there were also extra sweets and another round of drinks on the house. Would definitely recommend for someone dining late in the Plaza Mayor area. Really great value for very good good in a touristy area.

review_preview: Originally planned on having a quiet dinner for our final night in Madrid, so we decided to head to a Portuguese restaurant on Calle Mendizábal, but it was closed for the summer. Luckily, I remembered seeing rave reviews about Origen (which was on the same...
review_full: Originally planned on having a quiet dinner for our final night in Madrid, so we decided to head to a Portuguese restaurant on Calle Mendizábal, but it was closed for the summer. Luckily, I remembered seeing rave reviews about Origen (which was on the same street), so we ate there instead, and what a blessing it was. Ordered everything David, one of the wonderful servers there, recommended, and everything was superb. The ceviche, beef gyoza, and beef tartare(?) were notable, but the stars of the show were the huge sardines on toast and the cuttlefish burgers. The latter two were some of the best things we've ever had, and that is quite a statement.  As for the service, it was exceptional. There's no other way to put it. They were very engaging despite the hustle and bustle of the dinner service. Regards to David (in the photo), Emma and Mar, who definitely made our last (but not final) dinner in Madrid very memorable.

review_preview: We were really excited to try this restaurant after reading all the great reviews, but to say we were bitterly disappointed is an understatement. I thought about giving it 1/5, but to be fair, it's probably worthy of a 2 because it's clean, has a...
review_full: We were really excited to try this restaurant after reading all the great reviews, but to say we were bitterly disappointed is an understatement. I thought about giving it 1/5, but to be fair, it's probably worthy of a 2 because it's clean, has a lovely atmosphere and the food and decoration is presented very well. But beyond that, there wasn't much else this restaurant can be complimented on. Of the four mains we tried, the fish was very plain, the Spanish sweet and sour pork ok but nothing fantastic (but probably the best out of the four we tried), the volcano rice good, but have had much better and oh, the chicken? It wasn't cooked through. When we told the waiter, he said that it was ok to eat (though I will add he was very nice). Not sure about Spain, but where we're from, chicken isn't like steak, where rare or medium rare is ok; chicken should be cooked through. Anyway, the manager was called over, looked over and apathetically asked if we'd like the chicken to be cooked more. There was no apology, no nothing, and when it came back, it was so salty and overcooked, it would've been better to eat wood. You could not pay me enough to dine here again.

title_review: Scrumptuously updated take on Tapas and Spanish food

review_full: Taberna Origen was so good we went there twice, the first time for lunch and then again for dinner our last night in Madrid after traveling to Barcelona and Tarragona. Both the lunch and the dinner were outstanding. Every dish the chef proposed was exquisite, perfectly paired, unique, and beautifully presented. The tuna tartare with the avocado ice cream, black sesame sprouts and sour apple dots was soo good! The octopus was as tender and tasty as any I have ever had. Everything we tried was original and out of this world. I would have gone back a third time!

review_preview: We Found this place on trip advisor as it was close to our hotel and wow what a treat this place is.  So glad we gave it a go on our first night in Madrid.The waiter gave us some tips from the menu and...
review_full: We Found this place on trip advisor as it was close to our hotel and wow what a treat this place is. So glad we gave it a go on our first night in Madrid. The waiter gave us some tips from the menu and I have to say his choices were fab. We decided to have tapas and chose 5 dishes from the menu. The tomatoes with cheese and basil were AMAZING.... Roasted slowly for 14 hours - The braised veal was to die for too...it just fell apart... Shrimp crocquets were lovely as were the steamed roll with chicken ... The last dish with egg was good too. Cannot actually fault anything. We both had puddings and a couple of drinks and the bill was a very reasonable 67 euros.  The service was attentive, ambience was lovely and we had an amazing meal. Highly recommended.
